advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>A computer, which grows with your requirements</i> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Joscelyn Flores</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT JULY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"This flexibly expandable computer grows by the increase of business activities and the rising requirements."<br><br> A reliable office computer, which can flexibly adapt to the business work, as it is essential for the office to execute resulting works promptly, correctly, and precisely.<br> A user-friendly conceived EDP-system like the MZ-3541 is essential, particularly for small to medium sized companies.<br> The MZ-3541 contributes for a substantial increase of the productivity in the office by the assumption of routine works. SHARP has designed the new MZ-3541 in such a way that it can be used for the most diverse resulting office works. And because multiple peripheral devices are available, the system can grow dynamically with the business activities.<br><br> The MZ-3541 is the result of Sharp's extensive market study and ergonomics studies. The free mobile keyboard makes data input and the operation easier and allows for spatial conditions an adapted installation of the system possible.<br> Sharp's MZ-3541 - the complete system for the business data processing. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROF80 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert from Pentasonic stores chain.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one ! </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PASOPIA 16 JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris"><a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMC INTERNATIONAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>It seems that the CMC Company (We have no more info about this company) used SuperBrain systems in which they added various hard disks, from 5 to 20 MB. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - NOV.1981</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Imagine the new world that would unfold before you if you had a powerful , portable, completely integrated computer system at your personal disposal. And at an affordable price. That's exactly what Hewlett-Packard has just created.<br> At the lab, on your desk or in your study this 20-pound, self-contained system provides professional computing power when and where you need it. That means no more waiting for data to be remotely processed and returned.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE BUSINESS GRAPHICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Apple graphics package was launched in September 1982. It was available for both the Apple II and Apple III.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">As you know, one picture is worth a few thousand numbers.<br> As you may not know, Apple Business Graphics software can generate more types of pictures, in more colours, using more data than any other graphics package... On the monitor of your choice. And on virtually any printer or plotter on the market...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 ! <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARABIC MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>In late 1988, bilingual (arab / french) versions of the TO-7/70 were sold for peanuts. These models could display latin and arabic characters. The keyboard was also bilingual, as well as the Basic !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MENTA & SOFTY ADVERT (FRANCE, SEPT. 82)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC.1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA 1 PIN</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Suzy (16 MHz 16 bit blitter, GPU & math processor)
computer.cpu: Mikey (16 MHz 16 bit custom chip, 3.6 MHz 8 bit MOS 65C02 CPU, SPU, Video DMA)
computer.description:
Atari's first (and only) handheld console was released in 1989. Unfortunately for Atari though, Nintendo had recently released their all conquering Game Boy. Despite being technologically superior, the Lynx just couldn't compete.
Originally developed by software publisher Epyx and named Handy (which is also the name of one of the machines best emulators), financial difficulties meant a development partner was needed. A deal was agreed which would see Atari manufacture and market the machine while Epyx handled software development.
The Lynx was far more powerful than the Game Boy, using custom chips and benefiting from a 3.5" colour screen. It also had a duplicate set of buttons and the ability to flip the screen which meant it could be used left handed. However, the better specs meant that the Lynx could drain its batteries in just 4 hours! Sales were steady, but nothing like those of the cheaper Game Boy.
In 1991 a redesigned Lynx II arrived, featuring a backlit screen and stereo sound output. Battery life improved 25% to around 5 hours and a price drop to $99 helped sales but by this time the Lynx was already a long way behind. With Atari's popularity on the slide and the release of Sega's Game Gear in America and Europe the same year, which received numerous games already popular on Sega's home consoles, the Lynx was relegated to a distant third in the handheld battle.

emulator.description: Probably the best Lynx emulator available
emulator.name: Handy

computer.keyboard: 8-way d-pad, 2x A button 2x B button, Option 1, Option 2Power On button, Power Off button, Backlight button (Lynx II)
computer.name: Lynx/Lynx II
computer.power: 6x AA batteries/9 volt DC power adapter
computer.sound: 4 channel mono (Lynx II stereo), 8 bit DAC per channel
